reasoning: This targets a central load-bearing uncertainty in the paper’s Section 3.3: whether executed value-destroying threats are a small perturbation or a dominant EV sink, which would substantially flip priorities (threat-prevention institutions/norms vs expanding trade/compromise capacity). It is strongly paper-specific because the paper’s optimism about partial AM-convergence via moral trade is explicitly conditional on threats being rare and containable. The question is fairly clear and operationalisable (estimate a resource-share t; study how t changes with multipolarity/enforcement), and it includes explicit thresholds and strategic implications (excellent decision hook). Main weakness is tractability: ‘future resource share devoted to executed threats’ depends on hard-to-model strategic dynamics, commitment tech, and value pluralism; simulations/AI-agent bargaining experiments can give partial, model-dependent bounds but not decisive estimates soon. Some ambiguity remains about definitions (what counts as a ‘threat’, what qualifies as ‘value-destroying’, and what ‘resources’ means across cosmic/post-AGI contexts), but these can be pinned down in a research design.
title: Resource losses from executed threats in multipolar bargaining
